Query: How do I download a file from the internet to my linux server with Bash

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Delete multiple files on the remote server
Top-3 Similar Questions: su_891479: Download multiple files from ftp server with bash script
Top-3 Scripts:
su_891479: ftp -in ftp://user:pw@ftp.srv1.de << EOF
    binary
    cd Datenbankbackup
    mget *
EOF

Explanations about Options.-i: Turns off interactive prompting during multiple file transfers.
Explanations about Options.-n:
Restrains ftp from attempting “auto-login” upon initial connection. If auto-login is
 enabled, ftp will check the .netrc (see netrc(5)) file in the user's home directory
 for an entry describing an account on the remote machine. If no entry exists, ftp
 will prompt for the remote machine login name (default is the user identity on the
 local machine), and, if necessary, prompt for a password and an account with which to
 login.

so_22114610: aria2c -x 16 [url] #where 16 is the number of connections

Explanations about Options.-x: The maximum number of connections to one server for each download. Default: 1

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Copy a file between two remote hosts transferring through the local host
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_21621968: Download a file from a Server with double ssh
so_9427553: How to download a file from server using SSH?
ul_295704: How do I download a file from a host i'm already connected to over ssh
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_295704: scp xyz@remote:/home/user/test /home/user

[local] $ ssh -R 2222:localhost:22 remote
[remote]$ scp -P 2222 /home/user/test xyz@localhost:/home/user

Explanations about Options.-i:
Selects the file from which the identity (private key) for public key authentication
 is read. This option is directly passed to ssh(1).
Explanations about Options.-r:
Recursively copy entire directories. Note that scp follows symbolic links
 encountered in the tree traversal.
Explanations about Options.-P:
Specifies the port to connect to on the remote host. Note that this option is
 written with a capital ‘P’, because -p is already reserved for preserving the times
 and modes of the file.

so_68230707: Downloading a File from SSH with Sudo
Top-3 Scripts:
au_76239: rsync -rP -e ssh username@serveraddress:"directory/file" /destinationfolder/

e ssh

so_68230707: $ CONTENT=$(expect -c 'spawn ssh -t user@localhost "sudo cat /tmp/file.txt"; expect "password"; send "userpassword\r"; expect "password"; send "userpassword\r"; interact' | sed -n '4p')

$ CONTENT=$(expect -c 
       'spawn ssh -t user@localhost "sudo cat /tmp/deneme.txt";
        expect "password"; send "userpassword\r";       #for first prompt of remote connection.
        expect "password"; send "userpassword\r";       #for second prompt of sudo.
        interact' | sed -n '4p')                        #4th line displayed in the terminal is the file content.

$ expect -c 'spawn ssh -t user@localhost "sudo cat /tmp/file.txt"; expect "password"; send "userpassword\r"; expect "password"; send "userpassword\r"; interact'
spawn ssh -t user@localhost sudo cat /tmp/file.txt
user@localhost's password: 
[sudo] password for user: 
lorem ipsum dolor sit amet
Connection to localhost closed.

Explanations about Options.-t:
Force pseudo-terminal allocation. This can be used to execute arbitrary screen-
 based programs on a remote machine, which can be very useful, e.g. when implementing
 menu services. Multiple -t options force tty allocation, even if ssh has no local
 tty.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_58684175: Download latest file from remote server using curl
so_69816743: Download multiple files simultaneously with variable in URL with Curl
so_53134352: How to download images from Google with terminal? (Mac)
Top-3 Scripts:
so_58684175: P=https://website.com/remote/path
curl .. "$P/" > listing.txt
LATEST=$(sed -ne '/href=/{s@.*href=".*/\([0-9]\+_[^"]\+\).*@\1@p}' < listing.txt | sort -nr | head -1)
curl ... "$P/$LATEST"

so_53134352: curl -O https://i.imgur.com/PmPGYHR.png

curl https://imgur.com/gallery/yu5An |grep "link rel=\"image_src" |cut -d'"' -f4

Explanations about Options.--parallel-max:
When asked to do parallel transfers, using -Z, --parallel, this option controls the
 maximum amount of transfers to do simultaneously.
Explanations about Options.-O:
Write output to a local file named like the remote file we get. (Only the file part
 of the remote file is used, the path is cut off.)
Explanations about Options.--parallel:
Makes curl perform its transfers in parallel as compared to the regular serial
 manner.
